page.title: Negation Constructions - Type
page.introduction:
Languages fall into two major classifications with respect to negation: Polarity Changing languages versus Negative Concord languages, exemplified by standard English and Spanish or Black English, respectively.
Polarity Changing languages normally allow only a single negative element in the sentence for negation to be expressed (though technically any odd number of negatives expresses negative polarity) because the presence of two (or any even number of) negative elements changes the polarity back to positive. For example, John saw nothing is negative, but John didn't see nothing is positive because it means the same as John saw something. The version with a negative auxiliary is expressed as John didn't see anything, using what is known as a negative polarity item in object position. Such negative polarity items may occur as subjects in some contexts without any other negation present, such as Anyone may come, but they may only occur in object position when some higher (technically c-commanding) element is negative. For example, one can say Nobody saw anyone and Nowhere will they find anyone but without the negative subject or fronted negative adverb the negative auxiliary must be used, as in We did not see anyone and They will not find anyone anywhere.
In Negative Concord languages, any number of negative elements expresses negative polarity, so in a Negative Concord version of English (such as Black English) John didn't see nothing is the correct way to express a negative sentence with a negative object. In these languages, similarly to the restriction on negative polarity items above, a negative element may normally occur in subject position or a fronted position without any other negative element present, but a negative object may only occur when some higher (technically c-commanding) element is negative. Some Negative Concord languages have the stronger restriction that any negative argument must co-occur with verbal negation and still others require fronting of the negative argument, similarly to the fronting of question words or phrases in content questions.
(Click here to see more on c-command.)

form.prompt: Your language is neither Polarity changing nor Negative Concord, since the only way to express negation is via the verbal affix so there are not multiple instances of negation to change the polarity or to concord with. Since you will not be asked for further examples on this page, it is important that you be sure you gave sufficient examples showing the verbal negation on the previous page for use in the grammar writeup before continuing on.

radioGroup.prompt: Which type of negation does your language have?
radioGroup.radio: Polarity changing, like standard English, since the polarity changes between positive and negative with each instance of negation
Negative Concord, since any number of negative elements simply agree in making the polarity negative

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have negative polarity items?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, there is a separate set of pronouns, determiners, and adverbs which occur in object position or the normal adverb position instead of the equivalent negative item when another negative element is present in the sentence
No, the negative pronouns, determiners, and adverbs may occur in object position or the normal adverb position even when there is another negative element in the sentence

form.prompt: Key your examples of the various negative polarity items in the appropriate boxes, each on a separate line and followed by a period.
The negative polarity items which are pronouns, such as 'anyone', 'anybody', 'anything'. Include elements which mean the same, but are written as more than one word.
The negative polarity items which are determiners (special degree elements for your language), such as 'any':
The negative polarity items which are temporal adverbs, such as 'anytime':
The negative polarity items which are locative adverbs, such as 'anywhere':
form.instruction: Add the feature negative-polarity to all the negative polarity items, including the affix(es) used in the nominal phrase in place of the negative special degree affix(es) , though use instead the feature negative-polarity_prefix or negative-polarity_suffix for the negative-polarity proclitics and enclitics, respectively, used in the nominal phrase in place of the negative special degree clitic(s). Those which are adverbs also need either the feature temporal or locative as appropriate. You also need to make sure the categories are correct. If the pronouns (written as a single word including the negative polarity item) do not already have the category Pron, add the feature makePron to change the category for the syntax. If the adverbs do not already have the category Adv, add the feature makeAdv to change the category for the syntax. Add the feature Q to the negative polarity special degree words to change their category appropriately. Add the feature Det to the negative polarity determiners to change their category appropriately.
form.prompt: You gave the following examples of negative nominal phrases in subject position. (You may add any additional examples you think of.)
Special negative degree element modifying a subject nominal phrase:
Negative quantifier determiner modifying a subject nominal phrase:
Negative indefinite pronouns or nominal phrases as the subject of a full sentence:
Now give similar examples where the negative nominal phrase is in object position and the subject is positive.
Now give similar examples but with a positive subject and a negative polarity item in the object nominal phrase.
Sentence examples with a negative polarity item nominal phrase in object position:
Now give similar examples where the negative nominal phrase is an indirect object and the subject is positive.
Now give similar examples with a positive subject and a negative polarity item as the indirect object.
Sentence examples with a negative polarity item nominal phrase in indirect object position:
Finally, give examples where both the subject and object are negative.
Finally, give examples with a negative subject and a negative polarity item in the object nominal phrase.
Sentence examples with a negative subject and a negative polarity item nominal phrase in object position:

radioGroup.prompt: Looking back at the full sentence examples you have given, is the verb or auxiliary required to be negative when the object nominal phrase is negative? contains a negative polarity item?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, a negative polarity item in the object (or indirect object) is not allowed without also having a negative verb or auxiliary

No, the verb or auxiliary is not required to be negative when there is a negative polarity item in the object (or indirect object), but if it is not there must be some other (c-commanding) negative element in the sentence
No, there is no restriction about the presence of another negative element in the sentence when there is a negative polarity item in the object (or indirect object)

radioGroup.prompt: Is a negative object required to be fronted in all negation constructions in your language?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, a negative object must appear initially in the sentence, similarly to question phrases in English
A negative object may appear initially in the sentence, or it may remain in its normal position
A negative object may appear in the position directly before the verb, or it may remain in its normal position
No, a negative object simply appears in its normal position in the sentence
